revision_history.draft:
The clock’s gears gnaw their own bones  
into a dust of silver, each tooth  
a scar where seconds once clung.  
A tree’s rings, fragile as a moth’s wing,  
hold the weight of storms—  
each circle a question mark  
in the ledger of its breath.  

Time carves its name in the door’s hinge,  
rust blooming like a second skin,  
while the key, worn smooth as a sigh,  
forges its own oblivion.  
A hand, once bold in its grip,  
now trembles—  
a map of erosion,  
each line a bridge to nowhere.  

In the mirror’s cracked glass, a face  
is both sculpture and ghost,  
its edges blurred by the hands  
that once molded it.  
We are all relics of the same chisel,  
carving our own decay  
into the marble of the moment.

final_poem:
The clock’s gears gnaw their own bones  
into a dust of silver, each tooth  
a scar where seconds once clung.  
A tree’s rings, delicate as a moth’s wing,  
hold the weight of storms—  
each circle a silent query  
in the ledger of its breath.  

Time carves its name in the door’s hinge,  
rust blooming like a second skin,  
while the key, worn smooth as a sigh,  
forges its own erasure.  
A hand, once bold in its grip,  
now trembles—  
a cartography of erosion,  
each line a bridge to nowhere.  

In the mirror’s cracked glass, a face  
is both sculpture and specter,  
its edges blurred by the hands  
that once molded it.  
We are all relics of the same chisel,  
carving our own decay  
into the marble of the present.
